item.title: HTMX + 3rd Party Libraries The Easy Way.
item.dc:creator: Berel Levy
item.content:encoded:
Easily activate HTMX on all elements added to the DOM by 3rd party libraries etc. with one simple codeÂ snippet.

The TL;DR

If you just want to solution, here it is. Run this code snippet once on page-load to call htmx.process(el) on every element subsequently added to the DOM not byÂ htmx.

const observer = new MutationObserver((mutations) => {
  mutations.forEach((mutation) => {
    mutation.addedNodes.forEach((node) => {
      if (node.nodeType === 1 && !node["htmx-internal-data"]) {
        htmx.process(node)
      }
    })
  })
})
observer.observe(document, {childList: true, subtree: true})

If you want to better understand how this works, and to improve your knowledge of htmx and the DOM in general, readÂ on.

The Full Explanation

NOTE: This article assumes you use htmx and have at least basic knowledge of how it works. For a tutorial the docs are excellent.

Whenever an element is added to DOM, htmx runshtmx.process(el) on the element to register it and store some metadata on the element so that htmx can work itâ€™s ajax goodness when called upon later (read: when clicked). htmx.process(el) runs in two situations:

  1. On initial pageÂ load.
  2. 2. When an element is added to the DOM byÂ htmx.

But htmx has no way of knowing when an element has been added to the DOM by a 3rd party library or by yourÂ code.

To fix this you can run htmx.process(el) manually on every element that your code adds to the DOM. Read more about this in the htmx docs here. This works perfectly of course, but it can be tedious and error prone. And it can sometimes be convoluted to intercept an element added by a 3rd partyÂ library.

It would be much better if we could just watch the dom for changes and run htmx.process(el) whenever an element is added to theÂ DOM.

MutationObserver

Luckily, the browser offers us the MutationObserver API, which allows us to listen for any changes to a DOM element just like we can listen to events. ChangesÂ include:

  1. Child elements added orÂ removed.
  2. Changes to the text inside anÂ element.
  3. Changes to an elementâ€™s attributes.

We can then run any code we like on those elements.

Try itÂ Out.

Letâ€™s see the MutationObserver in action. If you are reading this on desktop, open the console and run this codeÂ snippet:

new MutationObserver((mrs) => console.log(mrs)).observe(document, { childList: true, subtree: true })

This will register a MutationObserver that will log all MutationEvents to the console. Select some text in this article. You should see some MutationRecords logged. Every time you select some text in a medium article, some JS adds those elements to the DOM, and removes them from the DOM when the text is unselected.

If you drill down into a MutationRecord, youâ€™ll see a property called addedNodes which contains the elements that wereÂ added.

Letâ€™s take a slightly more in depth look into how MutationObserver works.

First we create a new mutation observer. It takes one argument, a callback function that will run for every mutation event. The callback receives one argument, mutationRecords; which is an array containing one or more objects. Each object contains information about a mutation that has taken place. Letâ€™s just log the mutationRecords argument to the console forÂ now.

const observer = new MutationObserver((mutationRecords) => {
  console.log({mutationRecords})
})

If you run this code, nothing will happen, because this observer needs something to observe. Letâ€™s give it something to observe by calling itâ€™s observe method. This method takes two arguments: target and options. target is the element we will er, observe, and options, well you probably know what options are. letâ€™s add the the observer to our code and then Iâ€™ll explain which options we need toÂ use.

const observer = new MutationObserver((mutationRecords) => {
  console.log({mutationRecords})
})
observer.observe(document, { childList: true, subtree: true })     // NEW
// note: you can test this code in the console.

We pass 2 parameters in options; childList: true and subtree: true. They sound similar but are actually quite different.

childList: true tells the observer what type of changes we want to observe. In our case we want to observe our target element, the document, for any added or removed child nodes (elements are nodes, but nodes can also be other things). we can then access those nodes in mutationRecord.addedNodes, and mutationRecord.removedNodes, respectively, in the callback function.

By the way, we can also observe the target for attribute changes (e.g. class or id) and text changes but we wonâ€™t explore those in thisÂ article.

subtree: true tells the observer to also watch all of the targetâ€™s descendent nodes for these changes as well, not just theÂ target.

In summary, our callback will now run whenever any elements are added to the DOM. Now, letâ€™s run some code on those elements.

Watch it,Â htmx

The mutationRecords argument is an array of MutationRecord objects. letâ€™s loop through them now and log each one separately.

const observer = new MutationObserver((mutationRecords) => {
  mutationRecords.forEach((mutationRecord) => {               // NEW
    console.log(mutationRecord)                               // NEW
  })                                                          // NEW
})
observer.observe(document, { childList: true, subtree: true })
// note: you can test this code in the console.

Each MutationRecord object has a property called addedNodes: a nodeList of all the nodes that were added in this mutation, but you could have guessed that yourself. Letâ€™s loop through that and log each nodeÂ now.

const observer = new MutationObserver((mutationRecords) => {
  mutationRecords.forEach((mutationRecord) => {              
    mutationRecord.addedNodes.forEach((node) => {            // NEW
      console.log(node)                                      // NEW
    })                                                       // NEW
  })                      
})
observer.observe(document, { childList: true, subtree: true })
// note: you can test this code in the console.

Finally, letâ€™s run htmx.process(el) on any elements that needÂ it.

const observer = new MutationObserver((mutationRecords) => {
  mutationRecords.forEach((mutationRecord) => {
    mutationRecord.addedNodes.forEach((node) => {               
      if (node.nodeType === 1 && !node["htmx-internal-data"]) {  // NEW
        htmx.process(node)                                       // NEW
      }                                                          // NEW
    })
  })
})
observer.observe(document, { childList: true, subtree: true })
// NOTE: this code needs htmx to run.

First we check for nodes that are DOM elements (node type 1, read more), then we check that the element wasnâ€™t added by htmx, which adds the htmx-internal-data attribute to elements. For all nodes that match, we run htmx.process(node) and these elements are good toÂ go!

I hope you enjoyed this article. HappyÂ coding.

item.title: Out-Of-This-World Django DX
item.dc:creator: Berel Levy
item.content:encoded:
How to set up the Jupyter Notebook VSCode extension inÂ Django.

Whatâ€™s Wrong with Earthâ€™sÂ Shell?

Testing code in the shell is a necessary part of django development, that goes without saying. But itâ€™s an experience that leaves you wanting. The improvements suggested in Boost Your Django DX (Great book. Read it.) help a lot, but thereâ€™s something evenÂ better.

Imagine you could run your code right inside the file youâ€™re editing! You get access to all the benefits available in your editor (intellisense, ctrl+clicking, etc.) and run it right then and there, fast as a repl. You can all this and more, with Jupyter Notebook.

Server orÂ Plugin?

Jupyter Notebook comes in two flavors; as a web page and as an integrated VSCode plugin. The web page version is easier to get started with but the plugin version is much better. Iâ€™ll be showing you how to use the plugin version because thatâ€™s what I like, and thereâ€™s already an article that shows you how to set up the web page version: How to use Django in Jupyter Notebook by Ayuth Mangmesap.

Getting Started.

Make sure you have VSCode installed.

1. Install the Jupyter VSCode Extension

2. Make sure you have a virtual environment set up. If you donâ€™t you can set one up by typingpython -m venvÂ .venv into your terminal.

3. Next, install the Jupyter python library by typing pip install jupyter into your terminal.

4. Open the VSCode command palette (â‡§âŒ˜P on mac, ctrl+shift+p on windows) and choose the Python: Select Interpreter command.

4a. Choose the interpreter from your virtual environment. It will be something like path-to-your-venv/bin/python, if you created the virtual environment using python -m venvÂ .venv it should look like the selection below.

Your Jupyter Notebook will use this interpreter and stay in sync with your projectâ€™s dependencies.

5. Create a jupyter notebook file like dev.ipynb in the root directory of your django project, next to your manage.py file. Since youâ€™ll be using this file in dev itâ€™s a good idea to add it to yourÂ .gitignore.

5a. Open the dev.ipynb file. It should look likeÂ this:

6. Click on the Select Kernel button, in the top right corner of the open Notebook.

6a. Select the Python Environmentsâ€¦ option. Then choose your projectâ€™s virtual environment. Itâ€™s the same one you chose in the Python: Select Interpreter menuÂ above.

Congratulations! Youâ€™ve set up Jupyter Notebook. You should now be able to run vanilla python in it, try something simple, like a print statement.

Using Django in Your Jupyter Notebook.

If you try to do anything Django-related youâ€™ll get an error like
ImproperlyConfigured: Requested setting INSTALLED_APPS, but settings are not configured. You must either define the environment variable DJANGO_SETTINGS_MODULE or call settings.configure() before accessing settings. This is because a lot of setup happens when django starts up when you run python manage.py COMMAND and weâ€™ll need to replicate this in the beginning of our Notebook to access all our DjangoÂ stuffs.

Add the following code to the firstÂ cell:

import os, django 
os.environ["DJANGO_SETTINGS_MODULE"] = "<your.settings.module>" 
os.environ["DJANGO_ALLOW_ASYNC_UNSAFE"] = "true"              
django.setup()

The last line, django.setup() is the magic command that does what is says it does. This is what gets called early on when you run manage.py COMMAND.

The line above that, os.environ[â€œDJANGO_ALLOW_ASYNC_UNSAFEâ€] = â€œtrueâ€ ensures that the ORM works smoothly in Jupyter Notebook. I wonâ€™t get into it here, but in short, Jupyter is async and the ORM isnâ€™t. Just be carefull, donâ€™t change this setting in your settings file because itâ€™s bad for production.

The first two lines are pretty self explanatory.

Test itÂ Out!

You can now test some Django code in Notebook and it will run properly, just like it would in theÂ shell.

Autoreload

Add the following code above the django related code at the beginning of the first cell of your jupyter notebook:

%reload_ext autoreload        # NEW
%autoreload 2                 # NEW

import os, django 
os.environ["DJANGO_SETTINGS_MODULE"] = "<your.settings.module>" 
os.environ["DJANGO_ALLOW_ASYNC_UNSAFE"] = "true"              
django.setup()

This will reload everything whenever you change something in another file, similar to how runserver reloads when you change something. Unlike runserver however, you donâ€™t lose all your variables. Also, since Django runs a lot of setup in the beginning, sometimes youâ€™ll need to restart the whole Notebook from fresh. You can do this by clicking on the restart button on the top of the Notebook.

Thatâ€™s it. Happy coding, and Iâ€™ll leave you to get aquainted with the joys of Jupyter NoteBook.

Check out https://code.visualstudio.com/docs/datascience/jupyter-notebooks for more info on customizing the Jupyter VSCode extension.

item.title: Adding Star Power to Django QuerySets
item.dc:creator: Berel Levy
item.content:encoded:
Adding the convenience of SQLâ€™s SELECT * to Djangoâ€™s QuerySet.values().

Itâ€™s a story is as old as time itself, youâ€™re browsing a modelâ€™s data and you donâ€™t want to type out every column name, so you leave qs.values() empty. Everythingâ€™s peachy, until you want to also include a column from a related model. Uh oh, when you add it, qs.values() only returns that column! Now you have to write all the column names of the first model asÂ well.

What to do? If only there were a way to add that ability to the qs.values()methodâ€¦

There is a way! Using basic inheritance you can override Djangoâ€™s QuerySet methods and add new functionality, like accepting a "*â€ for example. Letâ€™s learnÂ how.

Overriding the baseÂ model.

Since all your models inherit from Djangoâ€™s models.Model already, you can easily create your own custom base model and all the models in your project can inherit from it instead. Letâ€™s start creating our own BaseModel in a new file weâ€™ll call base_model.py.

# base_model.py
from django.db import models

class BaseModel(models.Model):
  
    class Meta:
        abstract = True # this ensures no migrations will be created.

Now all the models in your project can safely inherit from this BaseModel instead of Djangoâ€™s models.Model. ForÂ Example:

# main/app/models.py

from django.db import Models
from base_model import BaseModel

class MyFirstModel(BaseModel)
    field1 = models.CharField(
        max_length=255, 
        default="Look ma, no input!"
    )

MyFirstModel's behavior wonâ€™t change at all since it gets all the models.Model functionality through BaseModel. Better still, you can try adding a custom method to BaseModel and testing it on yourÂ model.

Adding a BaseManager and BaseQueryset.

SinceÂ .values() is a QuerySet method, weâ€™ll have to override the default QuerySet and have our BaseModel use that one. Lets add some code to base_model.py above our BaseModel definition.

# base_model.py
from django.db import models

class BaseManager(models.Manager):    # NEW
    pass                              # NEW


class BaseModel(models.Model):

    objects = BaseManager()           # NEW

    class Meta:
        abstract = True

Wait, werenâ€™t we adding a queryset? Why is it called Manager? Unfortunately, in Django, models donâ€™t have QuerySets. They have Managers, and Managers have QuerySets. I donâ€™t know why we need the Manager in the middle, in fact I think heâ€™s only a manager because heâ€™s related to someone. But, this is how itâ€™s done, so letâ€™s bear it. Now letâ€™s finally add our custom BaseQuerySet to the manager so we can get to the fun part, adding custom QuerySetÂ methods!

# base_model.py

from django.db import models

class BaseQuerySet(models.QuerySet):                       # NEW
    pass                                                   # NEW
    # fun stuff goes here.


class BaseManager(models.Manager):
    def get_queryset(self) -> BaseQuerySet:                # NEW
        return BaseQueryset(self.model, using=self._db)    # NEW


class BaseModel(models.Model):

    objects = BaseManager()

    class Meta:
        abstract = True

SQL, the Gold Standard.

The behavior weâ€™re gonna add is similar to SQLâ€™s SELECT *. the * represents all the columns in a given table, but you can still specify individual columns by name as well, so SELECT col1, * FROM tbl1 will return col1, followed by all the columns of tbl1. Conversely, SELECT *, col1 FROM tbl1 will select all the columns of tbl1 followed byÂ col1.

So what weâ€™re looking to do is override the qs.values() method before is it actually goes and fetches any data and have it check to see if any of the args passed in are a â€œ*â€ and then replace that arg with all the column names of theÂ model.

First, letâ€™s override the qs.values() method to see where exactly we will do allÂ this.

# base_model.py

from django.db import models

class BaseQuerySet(models.QuerySet):
    def values(self, *fields, **expressions):              # NEW
        # change *fields here
        # and then pass on to super.
        return super().values(*fields, **expressions)      # NEW


class BaseManager(models.Manager):
    def get_queryset(self) -> BaseQuerySet:
        return BaseQueryset(self.model, using=self._db)


class BaseModel(models.Model):

    objects = BaseManager()

    class Meta:
        abstract = True

As you can see in the code above, before we call super().values(), we can make changes toÂ *fields.

Letâ€™s break down what we want to do, in pseudo-code, if youÂ will.

  • Get a list of all the column names for ourÂ model
  • Check *fields for an arg that isÂ â€œ*â€
  • Replace that arg with the list of our modelâ€™s columnÂ names

Getting a List of Our Modelâ€™s ColumnÂ Names

First we need to get a list of all the modelâ€™s column names. hereâ€™s how: Model._meta.fields returns a list of the field objects that belong to this model. Each field object has a name property which returns a string of the fieldsÂ name.

Try this out in the shell: [f.name for f in MyFirstModel._meta.fields].

Now that we know how to get this list from the model, letâ€™s get access to it inside the queryset. Accessing the model inside the queryset is easy because when the queryset is instantiated, the model is passed in as a property. So we can access it as self.model. Letâ€™s add a calculated property to our BaseQuerySet called _column_names.

queeeee# base_model.py

from django.db import models

class BaseQuerySet(models.QuerySet):
    @property                                               # NEW
    def _column_names(self) -> list[str]:                   # NEW
        return [f.name for f in self.model._meta.fields]    # NEW

    def values(self, *fields, **expressions):
        # change *fields here
        # and then pass on to super.
        return super().values(*fields, **expressions)


class BaseManager(models.Manager):
    def get_queryset(self) -> BaseQuerySet:
        return BaseQueryset(self.model, using=self._db)


class BaseModel(models.Model):

    objects = BaseManager()

    class Meta:
        abstract = True

Since _column_names is an convenience method only meant to break up the logic into smaller parts and is not meant to be used outside the object we we add an underscore prefix to the propertyÂ name.

Checking for â€œ*â€ inÂ *fields

Now the fun starts. Letâ€™s add some code that does two things. 1) print *fields every time we call qs.values(). 2) remove the â€œ*â€ from *fields. Since itâ€™s not one of the recognized model fields, passing a â€œ*â€ to super().values() will raise an error. NOTE: SinceÂ .values() is a core QuerySet method, we need to be VEEEERRRRRYYYY careful when we overrideÂ it.

# base_model.py

from django.db import models

class BaseQuerySet(models.QuerySet):
    @property
    def _column_names(self) -> list[str]:
        return [f.name for f in self.model._meta.fields]

    def values(self, *fields, **expressions):
        print(fields)                                 # NEW
        fields = [f for f in fields if f != "*"]      # NEW
        return super().values(*fields, **expressions)

class BaseManager(models.Manager):
    def get_queryset(self) -> BaseQuerySet:
        return BaseQueryset(self.model, using=self._db)

class BaseModel(models.Model):

    objects = BaseManager()

    class Meta:
        abstract = True

And test it. Be sure to test different scenarios to make sure that qs.values() still works as expected.

Replacing â€œ*â€ With the Modelâ€™s ColumnÂ Names

Before we go ahead and actually replace the â€œ*â€, letâ€™s just confirm that we have access to the modelâ€™s column names inside theÂ .values() method. This might seem unnecessary, but since weâ€™re elbow deep in Djangoâ€™s innards, it pays not to take anything forÂ granted.

# base_model.py

from django.db import models

class BaseQuerySet(models.QuerySet):
    @property
    def _column_names(self) -> list[str]:
        return [f.name for f in self.model._meta.fields]

    def values(self, *fields, **expressions):
        print(self._column_names)                      # CHANGED
        fields = [f for f in fields if f != "*"]      
        return super().values(*fields, **expressions)

class BaseManager(models.Manager):
    def get_queryset(self) -> BaseQuerySet:
        return BaseQueryset(self.model, using=self._db)

class BaseModel(models.Model):

    objects = BaseManager()

    class Meta:
        abstract = True

Go ahead and test outÂ .values() again to see if it prints out the list of column names successfully.

Next, letâ€™s replace the â€œ*â€ in *fields with self._column_names. Weâ€™ll make a small change in the list comprehension to insert self._column_names when we remove the â€œ*â€. Letâ€™s also remove print(self._column_names) and add a print statement below the list comprehension to see our combinedÂ lists.

# base_model.py

from django.db import models

class BaseQuerySet(models.QuerySet):
    @property
    def _column_names(self) -> list[str]:
        return [f.name for f in self.model._meta.fields]

    def values(self, *fields, **expressions):              
        fields = [                                   # CHANGED
            f for f in fields                        # CHANGED
            if f != "*" else self._column_names      # CHANGED
        ]                                            # CHANGED
        print(fields)                                # NEW
        return super().values(*fields, **expressions)

class BaseManager(models.Manager):
    def get_queryset(self) -> BaseQuerySet:
        return BaseQueryset(self.model, using=self._db)

class BaseModel(models.Model):

    objects = BaseManager()

    class Meta:
        abstract = True

â€¦and test that as well. Two things should happen, first, you should see the combined list of fields printed out, and second, you should get an error TypeError: unhashable type: â€˜listâ€™. If look closely at the at the printed fields, youâ€™ll notice that the â€œ*â€ was replaced with a list of strings, and qs.values() only accepts strings in *fields, notÂ lists.

To fix this weâ€™ll define a function named flatten that flattens nested lists and use said function to flatten fields before we pass it to super().values() (that was starting to feel redundant). I wonâ€™t get into the nuances of how the flatten function works but I do recommend you read Fluent Python by Luciano Ramalho (pronounced â€œHah-MAHL-yuâ€, I believe) and Python Cookbook by David Beazley and Brian K. Jones to learn about that and much more. Actually I highly recommend you read through both of those books as they will give you a deep understanding of many of the most important aspects ofÂ python.

Letâ€™s first add the function and test it out to confirm that itÂ works.

# base_model.py

from django.db import models
from typing import Iterable                                       # NEW

def flatten(iterable: Iterable):                                  # NEW #
    """Flatten arbitrarily nested iterables."""                         #
    for i in iterable:                                                  #
        if isinstance(i, Iterable) and not isinstance(i, (str, bytes)): #
            yield from flatten(i)                                       #
        else:                                                           #
            yield i                                               # NEW #


class BaseQuerySet(models.QuerySet):
    @property
    def _column_names(self) -> list[str]:
        return [f.name for f in self.model._meta.fields]

    def values(self, *fields, **expressions):              
        fields = [
            f for f in fields
            if f != "*" else self._column_names
        ]
        return super().values(*fields, **expressions)

class BaseManager(models.Manager):
    def get_queryset(self) -> BaseQuerySet:
        return BaseQueryset(self.model, using=self._db)

class BaseModel(models.Model):

    objects = BaseManager()

    class Meta:
        abstract = True

Test the flatten function as follows: flatten(["a", ["b"]]) and it should output <generator object flatten at 0x00MEMADDRESS>, so pass it to list: list(flatten([â€œaâ€, [â€œbâ€]])) and it should output a flat list ["a",Â "b"].

Once weâ€™ve confirmed that flatten works properly, letâ€™s use it in qs.values()!

# base_model.py

from django.db import models
from typing import Iterable

def flatten(iterable: Iterable):
    """Flatten arbitrarily nested iterables."""
    for i in iterable:
        if isinstance(i, Iterable) and not isinstance(i, (str, bytes)):
            yield from flatten(i)
        else:
            yield i


class BaseQuerySet(models.QuerySet):
    @property
    def _column_names(self) -> list[str]:
        return [f.name for f in self.model._meta.fields]

    def values(self, *fields, **expressions):              
        fields = [
            f for f in fields
            if f != "*" else self._column_names
        ]
        fields = list(flatten(fields))                  # NEW
        return super().values(*fields, **expressions)

class BaseManager(models.Manager):
    def get_queryset(self) -> BaseQuerySet:
        return BaseQueryset(self.model, using=self._db)

class BaseModel(models.Model):

    objects = BaseManager()

    class Meta:
        abstract = True

Thatâ€™s it! you can now pass a â€œ*â€ to qs.values() and it should work as expected!

One more thing. Itâ€™s never a good idea to use a SELECT * query in production. Instead, always specify every column you need in your queries. I recommend you only enable this in dev mode. To achieve that letâ€™s test for Djangoâ€™s DEBUG mode before allowing this code toÂ run.

# base_model.py

from typing import Iterable
from django.db import models
from djang.conf import settings                          # NEW

def flatten(iterable: Iterable):
    """Flatten arbitrarily nested iterables."""
    for i in iterable:
        if isinstance(i, Iterable) and not isinstance(i, (str, bytes)):
            yield from flatten(i)
        else:
            yield i

class BaseQuerySet(models.QuerySet):
    @property
    def _column_names(self) -> list[str]:
        return [f.name for f in self.model._meta.fields]

    def values(self, *fields, **expressions):
        if settings.DEBUG:                                # NEW
            fields = [
                f for f in fields
                if f != "*" else self._column_names
            ]
        fields = list(flatten(fields))
        return super().values(*fields, **expressions)


class BaseManager(models.Manager):
    def get_queryset(self) -> BaseQuerySet:
        return BaseQueryset(self.model, using=self._db)


class BaseModel(models.Model):

    objects = BaseManager()

    class Meta:
        abstract = True

Have fun. I hope you enjoyed this article. Please feel free to leave comments and questions, Iâ€™ll try to respond to everything.

item.title: Pause/Play YouTube with Your Keyboard!!!
item.dc:creator: Berel Levy
item.content:encoded:
Letâ€™s make a keyboard shortcut that you can click in any active window that will pause your YouTube tutorial.

Step 1. Get the Chrome Extension

Add the Streamkeys chrome extension. download itÂ here.

Click on the extension and go to settings.

In the settings page, click the â€˜generalâ€™ section of theÂ sidebar.

item.title: Making a pagination based infinite scroll as a beginnerâ€Šâ€”â€Šon the backend.
item.dc:creator: Berel Levy
item.content:encoded:
Making a pagination based infinite scroll as a beginnerâ€Šâ€”â€Šon theÂ backend.

This is not a definitive guide and itâ€™s also not optimal, however, it works and it explains the conceptÂ well.

Tech stack: Ruby on Rails for the backend, React and Redux on the frontend (stayÂ tuned).

Note: cursor based navigation is better, but Iâ€™ve only just learned about it, so when I implement it, Iâ€™ll write a post aboutÂ it.

The first thing we need to do is paginate the data on the back end. (paginate = divide the data up intoÂ pages.)

so when our posts controller requests an index of posts from model, it needs to specify which page itÂ wants.

The model receives this request and needs to know one more thing, how many items to display per page. For now weâ€™ll keep that hardcoded.

Letâ€™s explain some of the codeÂ above.

line 2. page_qty = 5 sets the amount of items each â€˜pageâ€™Â has.

Line 3. offset = page_num * page_qty is how weâ€™ll tell our database exactly which record to begin with. Iâ€™ll explain this in detail in the next two lines ofÂ code.

Line 4. Thereâ€™s a lot happening on line 4, Iâ€™ll assume you are familiar with Railsâ€™ sql methods and Iâ€™ll explain what each one accomplishes in our context. One important point that Iâ€™ll make here is that chaining multiple sql methods still results in one sql query. Thatâ€™s one of the great advantages of Railsâ€™ sql query methods. now letâ€™s break itÂ down.

Post.order(updated_at:Â :desc): creates a sql query that looks something likeÂ this:

SELECT "posts".* FROM "posts" ORDER BY "posts"."updated_at" DESC

pretty neat,Â no?

.where(user_id: followees_ids): A little background here, the followees_ids method returns an array of ids of users that our current user follows which is his feed, by definition. This is probably not the best way to make the query, but it works, and it illustrates an important point; that you can pass an array of values to the where method. This is super cool and our sql query is now changed, and it looks likeÂ this:

SELECT "posts".* FROM "posts" WHERE "posts"."user_id" IN ($1, $2) ORDER BY "posts"."updated_at" DESC

Passing an array to the where method causes the WHERE clause to use IN () rather than =. In the example above, I passed an array containing twoÂ items.

.limit(page_qty): This is where the pagination starts to happen, we tell the database that we only want 5 records at aÂ time.

SELECT "posts".* FROM "posts" WHERE "posts"."user_id" IN ($1, $2) ORDER BY "posts"."updated_at" DESC LIMIT $3

As you probably realized, the $3 placeholder contains the number 5. If we stop here, the database would only send us the first 5 records. How do we tell the database to send us the next 5Â records?

.offset(offset): This last method tells our database where to start. Remember, on line 3. offset = page_num * page_qty and page_qty always means 5, so letâ€™s visualize some examples.

offset = 0 * 5 # page 0 - records 0 through 4.
offset = 1 * 5 # page 1 - records 5 through 9.
offset = 2 * 5 # page 2 - records 10 through 14.
etc.

so now weâ€™ve simplified our so that our frontend just need to send the page number to communicate which â€˜pageâ€™ of posts weÂ want.

In the next blog post, Iâ€™ll show you how I crafted the frontend to a. know when the user scrolls to the bottom of the page, and b. send for the next â€˜pageâ€™ ofÂ results.

item.title: Closure in Javascript
item.dc:creator: Berel Levy
item.content:encoded:
what is closure? Thereâ€™s a short answer and a longÂ answer.

The short answer is: read the longÂ answer.

Long Answer

You know how variables declared inside a function disappear once the function is done? Weeeellllâ€¦ that doesnâ€™t always happen. and hereâ€™sÂ why.

Youâ€™re dead if nobody knowsÂ you

first letâ€™s understand why those variables disappear. JavaScript has something called garbage collection. Garbage collection is a very descriptive and un-technical name for the rules JavaScript follows to free up memory used by variables. One of the rules of garbage collection is that once a variable is not referenced by any other code it is trashed, well, removed from memory, but â€˜trashedâ€™ has more emotion. The life of a variable is fickle,Â indeed.

we might now be able to understand why variables defined inside a function will disappear once the function is done. Since no other code has access to that inner scope, we can assume that no other code references that variable.

We can also make a nice, simple rule and assume that there is no way any code outside a function can ever reference a variable inside a function, right?Â Right???

Wrong.

Letâ€™s remember two other quirks that come with our beloved JavaScript; Lexical Scope and First-Class Functions. While we wonâ€™t deep dive into these concepts right now, letâ€™s try to summarize them accurately.

  1. Lexical scope: Functions have access to variables defined in their outerÂ scope.
  2. First-Class Functions: Function definitions (and uninvoked ones at that!) can be passed around like regularÂ data.

Suppose we define a function, letâ€™s name itÂ mommy,

function mommy() {
  
}

Inside this function we define another function, weâ€™ll name itÂ baby,

function mommy() {
  const baby = () => {
    console.log('kick!')
  }
}

But we donâ€™t invoke baby, instead, we return this inner function from the outer function.

function mommy() {
  const baby = () => {
    console.log('wah!')
  }
  return baby
}

So now, when we assign the return value of the mommy function to a new variable, letâ€™s call it baby asÂ well,

function mommy() {
  const baby = () => {
    console.log('wah!')
  }
  return baby
}
let baby = mommy()

Why? because the return value of mommy is the â€˜babyâ€™ function definition. so this new variable outside of mommy contains the function that was defined inside ofÂ mommy.

function mommy() {
  const baby = () => {
    console.log('wah!')
  }
  return baby
}
let baby = mommy()
baby()
// -> 'wah!'

Suppose, before we defined baby, we defined another variable name â€˜aâ€™, and we assigned it the value ofÂ 0.

function mommy() {
  let a = 0
  const baby = () => {
    console.log(a)
  }
  return baby
}
let baby = mommy()

Quick question, does baby have access to this variable? yes. one more question, when we return the baby function from the mommy, and assign it to a variable that is outside of mommy, does it still have access to the a variable a defined inside mommy??Â YES.

function mommy() {
  let a = 0
  const baby = () => {
    console.log(a)
  }
  return baby
}
let baby = mommy()
baby()
// -> 0
// ğŸ¤¯

One last question, suppose, inside our baby function, we made changes to the variable â€˜aâ€™ that is inside mommy, would those changes stick around even if we call baby once itâ€™s outside mommy?? Would theyÂ stick???

function mommy() {
  let a = 0
  const baby = () => {
    console.log(a)
    a++
  }
  return baby
}
let baby = mommy()
baby()
// -> 0
baby()
// -> 1

Yes, yes! A thousand timesÂ yes!

That mind twister is closure. Since the baby function has access to the variable â€˜aâ€™ and references it, the garbage collector doesnâ€™t trash it! and the mommy function doesnâ€™t finish running. Our baby now has access to the variable a for as long as baby is alive. baby can call it, change it and play with it as much as we like. If you think of assigning the return value of mommy to a variable as birth, you can think of closure as not cutting the umbilical cord.

Why ever use closure???

The first reason is that once you are comfortable with closure it becomes a great tool to encapsulate functionality in a conciseÂ way.

The second reason is that it makes you look smart and the technical job market is getting very competitive. demand for a product or service usually increases before the supply increases, then the supply catches up to demand, and then supply surpasses demand. At first there was a strong demand for coders, and there werenâ€™t enough of us, then bootcamps exploded all over the place and there were enough coders, then of course along the way everybody heard that coding is a great profession so now everyone and their cousin wants to be a coder, so there are too many coders. We need to differentiate ourselves, first by writing blogs to show that we are passionate, then by using closure to show that we are smart, then writing blogs about closure to show that we are smart, passionate, and just a little sarcastic too.

I hope this blog had you giggling, or smirking, or even rolling your eyes, because remember, youâ€™re dead if nobody knowsÂ you.

item.title: Introducing FauxMeaux 2.0 (patent pending)
item.dc:creator: Berel Levy
item.content:encoded:
I am very excited to introduce a new concept in social media advertising that will benefit all parties involved.

The Problem: AdsÂ suck

Social media ads are disliked by most users. this is an unvalidated claim that Iâ€™m nevertheless comfortable making. A user scrolling through their feed has little or no interest in seeing ads. Additionally, an ad today will be disguised as a post or a tweet, with only a small indication that its promoted or sponsored.

The Solution: FauxMeaux 2.0

The concept is so simple, every nth post is covered by an ad. to get to the post you simply need tap or click on the ad, thi makes the ad go away, and now you can view the post. There are many positive implications to thisÂ method.

To get a better feel for the experience, please watch thisÂ video.

I will go through them by showing the problems theyÂ solve.

Problem: Users have mostly negative associations withÂ ads.

Solution: There are at least two positive associations from tapping the ad to see theÂ post;

  1. The satisfaction of cleaning up garbage by getting rid of theÂ post.
  2. The joy of uncovering a surprise. The user knows that beneath every ad lies the sweet surprise of a hiddenÂ post.

Problem: Users donâ€™t likeÂ ads.

Solution: tap them and they goÂ away!

Problem: Social media companies must track user activity to gain insight on their preferences.

Solution: Users are motivated to interact withÂ ads,

Problem: Gauging user sentiment towards ads is very difficult.

Solution: Users are highly motivated to interact with ads, therefore, itâ€™s not a stretch to offer some options like ğŸ‘ and â€˜donâ€™t show this adÂ againâ€™.

Problem: Ads are disguised asÂ posts.

Solution: Now, since users want to uncover the post beneath the ad, there is no longer a need to disguise them, in fact users will now be excited to see ads because they know there is a sweet surprise waiting for themÂ beneath.

Problem: Users have no motivation to interact withÂ ads.

Solution: There is a post waiting for you under this adâ€¦Â tap!

item.title: Converting to Polymorphism
item.dc:creator: Berel Levy
item.content:encoded:
For my Mod 3 project, I made an eCommercesque app. when I got to the stretch goal of adding purchasing capability, I noticed that my join table for items and purchases was identical to my join table for item and cart. additionally, whenever I would need to create a purchaseItem, I would have to also destroy the corresponding CartItem.

This got me thinking, what if I just made the cartItem polymorphic?

my schema looks something like:

Cart -< CartItem >- Item

My purchase would lookÂ like:

Purchase -< PurchaseItem >- Item

I wonâ€™t go into too much detail, but I began to realize that Purchase would share many methods with Cart, and PurchaseItem would share all the methods with CartItem. More than that, I realized that when I created a purchase out of a cart, I would be deleting the CartItems while creating the new PurchaseItems. So, why not use CartItems for purchases as well? Then I would be able to just switch the cartItem from referencing the cart to referencing the purchase, instead of needing to delete the existing cartItem while also making a new purchaseItem

To do so, the cart/purchase reference field in cartItems would need be polymorphic

What is Polymorphism?

Well, CartItem is a join table. On one end, CartItem joins to Item, on the other end, CartItem joins to Cart, or purchase. Huh? thatâ€™s right, every cartitem can can reference a cart or a purchase.

How do you doÂ that?

Short version: replace the cart_id field in cartitem with two fields, itemable_id and itemable_type. itemable means â€˜can be referenced by an itemâ€™, the name of the table referenced goes in itemable_type.

Next, use the gifts bequeathed to us by ApplicationRecord to make expoliting that relationship aÂ breeze.

Long version: implement it!

First letâ€™s add the polymorphic field to our model. Letâ€™s generate a migration, which should look likeÂ this:

Now cart Item can be related to any other model/table. so for the big picture some validation here would be inÂ order.

now to add the methods to cart andÂ purchase

See, the methods are exactly theÂ same!

Since this app is and will always be, in dev, I just need to remove the seed data before I could remove my cart. However, in production you would need to migrate the data from cart_id to itemable_id (and set itemable_type to â€˜Cartâ€™). The method would look something likeÂ this:

CartItem.all.each do |ci|
  ci.itemable = ci.cart
  ci.save
end

once your data has been migrated you can now safely delete the cart_id field from cartItem. See the code below hosted with Unicode U+2764 ï¸ U+FE0F byÂ github.

once this change is made TEST ALL YOUR METHODS IN CART AND CARTITEM. this is a huge change, so start with the most basic methods and work your wayÂ up.

In our case, All of our Cart methods still work, since cart still knows cartitem as cartitem, and cartitem doesnâ€™t have any methods that call on cart, so we are goodÂ there.

now to write the code to create the purchase.

Lines 5 thru 7 do the lifting, and as you can see, itâ€™s not thatÂ heavy.

item.title: When is a Tree Not a Tree?
item.dc:creator: Berel Levy
item.content:encoded:
When itâ€™s the DOM, and youâ€™re a beginner.

Struggling to understand the DOM? Itâ€™s not your fault, youâ€™re being taughtÂ wrong.

Calling the DOM a tree is accurate, once you are familiar with the DOM and trees, not the green leafy kind that you donâ€™t see in the city, but the tree data structure. But trying to explain the DOM to beginners as a tree is foolish, and a colossal waste ofÂ time

You see, as a beginner, being told that the DOM is a tree makes no sense and there are many ways that calling the DOM a tree makes it actually harder to understand.

Hereâ€™s why.

An Upside DownÂ Tree

It starts with being told that itâ€™s really an upside down tree, with the trunk, as the document object, being the â€˜topâ€™ of the tree. Well, for most people, an upside down tree is not a thing, and letâ€™s be thankful.

Whatâ€™s aÂ Node??

Then weâ€™re told about nodes on the DOM tree, and that they are like the branches. honestly, as a beginner, nodes sounded to me like an ugly parasitic growth a tree was unfortunate to have. it didnâ€™t sound like branches atÂ all.

A Tree Within aÂ Tree?

The last straw was when I was told that nodes contain other nodes. ok thatâ€™s enough, tree branches donâ€™t live inside other tree branches, they branch off them, outside. I did however, find this curiosity on my google journey, a bar inside a tree. https://mymodernmet.com/sunland-big-baobab-tree-bar/

By the way, I recommend you donâ€™t google â€˜tree inside a treeâ€™, some of the first results are horrifying.

Letâ€™s Try Something Else

The BoxÂ Model

I think the DOM is best explained as a big rectangle. Inside this rectangle, we can put text, pictures, or crucially, more rectangles. Guess what we can put inside those rectangles, thatâ€™s right! Text, images and more rectangles.

Now, the rectangles themselves are invisible, but you can add margins and padding around theÂ edges.

letâ€™s build a simple webpage to illustrate.

hereâ€™s what our webpage looks like atÂ first:

Nothing there? letâ€™s add a border to the very first rectangle.

We actually added two borders, one around the HTML rectangle, and another around the body rectangle. Notice that I didnâ€™t call them nodes, youâ€™reÂ welcome.

Itâ€™s All Rectangles.

Everything you add to your webpage is a rectangle. The header? Rectangle. Paragraphs? Rectangle. List? List item? Image? Span? Paragraph? Rectangle. Rectangle. Rectangle. Rectangle. Rectangle. Rectangle. Rectangle. Rectangle.

Take a look at what Iâ€™ve done to the web pageÂ now.

Nothing much to look at, just some snarky content like every other hastily conceived coding article on the internet.

but wait, whatâ€™s happening in thisÂ gif?

Cool, no? All I did was add some borders and margins to each rectangle and now you can clearly see each onÂ clearly.

So Hereâ€™s MyÂ Point.

When you hear â€˜DOMâ€™, think rectangle with stuff in it. When you hear â€˜nodeâ€™, â€˜elementâ€™ or â€˜tagâ€™, think rectangle with stuff inÂ it.

you can add backgrounds to these rectangles, you can round their corners until they look like a circle. but deep down, they will always remain, rectangles within rectangles within rectangles within rectangles within rectangles within rectangles within rectangles within rectangles within rectangles within rectangles within rectangles within rectangles. And they have stuff (text, images, more rectangles ğŸ¤¯, etc.) insideÂ them.

item.title: Biting Both Ends of the Login Sandwich
item.dc:creator: Berel Levy
item.content:encoded:
Iâ€™ll jump right in to a description of my first tango with setting up dual UIs in a single railsÂ app.

The app is a barebones food ordering app inspired by grubzhlub or stretchmarks

This can be accomplished in 4 steps. Letâ€™s take a quick look atÂ them.

  1. Add a login, includes login form, path, and controller method.
  2. Configure our app to allow a restaurant session.
  3. Address sharedÂ paths
  4. Restricting paths only available to one loginÂ type.

Add aÂ Login

Our new user type, restaurant, can share login pages with the original user type which is, ahem, called user. We just have to add aÂ form.

Add the following code to app/views/sessions/login.html.erb

<%= form_for :session, url: "/sessions/restaurant" do |f| %>
  <%= f.label :username %>
  <%= f.text_field :username %>
  <%= f.label :password %>
  <%= f.text_field :password %>
  <%= f.submit "login" %>
<% end %>

notice the new path on line one. letâ€™s add that path to routes.rb

post '/sessions/restaurant', to: 'sessions#create_restaurant', as: 'create_restaurant'

now add the #create_restaurant method to the sessions controller:

class SessionsController < ApplicationController
  ...
  def create_user
    ...
  end
  # new login method for restaurant (identical to create_user)
  def create_restaurant
    restaurant = Restaurant.find_by(username: params[:session[:username])
    if !restaurant
      flash[:error] = "Restaurant not found"
      redirect_to new_login_path
    elsif restaurant.authenticate(params[:session][:password])
      session[:restaurant_id] = restaurant.id
      redirect_to restaurant_path(restaurant)
    else
      flash[:error] = "Password incorrect"
      redirect_to new_login_path
    end
end

supposing correct credentials weâ€™re faced with two issues when redirecting to restaurant_path(restaurant).

  1. our app is set up to check for a user (sessions[:user_id) ]in the cookies, not a restaurant(sessions[:restaurant_id]). thankfully, this problem only has to be fixedÂ once.
  2. restaurant_path(restaurant) takes us to the restaurant show page that the user would see and is not suited for the restaurant userÂ type.

Configure our app to allow restaurant sessions

To fix our first problem, letâ€™s make a small change to the set_user method in the application controller.

class ApplicationController < ActionController::Base
  ...
  def set_user
    if session[:user_id]  # => new!
      @current_user = User.find_by(id: session[:user_id]) 
    elsif session[:restaurant_id]
      @current_restaurant = Restaurant.find_by(id: session[:restaurant_id])  # => new!
    end  # => new!
  end
  def auth_user
  ...
  end
end

Addressing SharedÂ Paths

we can fix our second problem in restaurants_controller#show by changing the variables and the view templateÂ .

class RestaurantsController < ApplicationController
  ...
  def show
    if session[:user_id]
      # variables for the user
      @restaurant = Restaurant.find(params[:id])
      @items = @restaurant.items
      @new_order = Order.new(restaurant: @restaurant)
      # renamed template for the user
      render 'show_for_user'
    elsif session[:restaurant_id]
      # new variables for the restaurant
      @restaurant = Restaurant.find(session[:restaurant_id])
      @items = @restaurant.items
      @open_orders = @restaurant.open_orders
      # new template for the restaurant
      render 'show_for_restaurant'
    end
  end
end

our new show_for_restaurant template will contain all the functionality we want to provide our restaurant and there is no way for the user to access that template. This solution can be applied to any path that is shared by the restaurant andÂ user.

Restricting Paths that are Only Available to one LoginÂ Type

Our final step is to restrict our restaurant from viewing user specific pages and vice versa, for example, the user editÂ page.

Letâ€™s address this in twoÂ places.

  1. Set the login_path to check for for user and restaurant in the sessionÂ hash.
class SessionsController < ApplicationController
  ...
  
  def login
    if session[:user_id]
      # existing redirect if user logged in
      redirect_to user_path(session[:user_id])
    elsif session[:restaurant_id]
      # new redirect if restaurant is logged in
      redirect_to restaurant_path(session[:restaurant_id])
  end
end

Our login path is now a convenient redirecting tool that we can use to redirect either user or restaurant in case one of them tries to access any forbidden page.

2. Placing the restriction.

Suppose our restaurant tries to access a users edit page by pasting the link directly into the browser, we can just add the following code to user_controller#edit:

class UsersController < ApplicationController
  ...
  def edit
    @user = User.find_by(id: params[:id])
    #prevent all but the current user from accessing the edit page
    return redirect_to new_login_path unless @user == @current_user
  end
end

since our login path will detect our user type for us, it will also work if a user from directly pasting another userâ€™s url into the browser to nefariously access their editÂ page.

Many thanks to Andrew Santos, one of my coaches at Flatiron School for guiding me in this endeavor.
